title: Import Python Project Tutorial with UV
text:
This document provides detailed instructions for setting up your Python environment for this course/workshop. You should have already read the information in the 00_setup_slides and completed the installation of Visual Studio Code and Python using uv by following Setup Notebook 01.







This method is recommended for newer programmers not yet familiar with git and Github and for any user who only needs a static copy of the repository.

open the chosen GitHub repository. In this tutorial, we will import the repository for Dartmouth Libraries‚Äô Python Essential Workshop Series.
Click the green ‚ÄúCode‚Äù button on the repository page
Select ‚ÄúDownload ZIP‚Äù
Extract the ZIP file to a memorable location (e.g., ~/Documents/Python-Courses/)
Important: To get updates, you‚Äôll need to re-download




This method is recommended for users familiar with git and Github, have git installed, have a Github account, and who wish to create a dynamic copy (‚Äúclone‚Äù) of the repository. A clone allows you to update your local repo when its online counterpart as been updated (using the pull command in git). It also allows you to push any changes you made locally back up to the remote repository, but only if the repository administrator has given you these privileges.
If you have Git installed:
# before cloning, move the current working directory to the folder where you want to clone this project
git clone [REPOSITORY-URL]
# for example:
# git clone git@github.com:Dartmouth-Libraries/py-essentials_ws.git
To update the local version of the repository after the online version has been updated:
git pull origin main






cd path/to/[repository-name]





You can tell if a repository is set up for uv if it has a uv.lock file in its root folder.
Run the following in the terminal:
# This creates a .venv directory and installs all packages
uv sync
This command:

Creates a virtual environment in .venv/
Installs Python if the correct version isn‚Äôt available
Installs all packages specified in pyproject.toml
Creates/updates uv.lock for reproducibility




Prior to uv, Python project dependencies were usually stored in a requirements.txt file. To install all dependencies from this file and convert the project to a uv project, run the following in the terminal:

First, initiate uv for this project:

uv sync



uv add -r requirements.txt
If this doesn‚Äôt provide desired results, review the documentation on this process in the uv guide.







Note: This may take 5-10 minutes on first run.
# Run the setup verification script
uv run python scripts/00_setup.py







Launch VS Code
File ‚Üí Open Folder
Select the course repository folder





Open Command Palette (Ctrl+Shift+P on Windows/Linux, Cmd+Shift+P on macOS)
Type ‚ÄúPython: Select Interpreter‚Äù
Choose the interpreter from .venv (it should show up as ./venv/bin/python or similar)

If the .venv interpreter doesn‚Äôt appear:

Click ‚ÄúEnter interpreter path‚Ä¶‚Äù
Navigate to: .venv/Scripts/python.exe (Windows) or .venv/bin/python (Mac/Linux)




When you open a .ipynb file:

VS Code will prompt you to select a kernel
Choose the same .venv Python interpreter





Open scripts/00_setup.py
You should see the Python version in the bottom-right status bar
Right-click in the editor ‚Üí ‚ÄúRun Python File in Terminal‚Äù







# Activate environment and run verification script
uv run python scripts/00_setup.py



You can also test manually:
# Check Python version
uv run python --version

# Test package imports
uv run python -c "import pandas; import numpy; import matplotlib; print('All packages loaded successfully!')"

# List installed packages
uv pip list






Solution: The installation directory isn‚Äôt in your PATH.
Windows:
Add %USERPROFILE%\.cargo\bin to your PATH environment variable.
macOS/Linux:
Add this to your ~/.bashrc, ~/.zshrc, or equivalent:
export PATH="$HOME/.cargo/bin:$PATH"
Then run: source ~/.bashrc (or ~/.zshrc)



Solution: uv can install Python for you:
uv python install 3.11
uv sync



Solution 1: Ensure you have build tools installed
Windows:

Install Visual Studio Build Tools

macOS:
xcode-select --install
Linux (Ubuntu/Debian):
sudo apt-get install build-essential python3-dev
Solution 2: Try installing pre-built wheels:
uv pip install --only-binary :all: [package-name]



Solution:

Make sure .venv folder exists in your project root
Reload VS Code (Ctrl+Shift+P ‚Üí ‚ÄúDeveloper: Reload Window‚Äù)
Manually browse to the interpreter:

-   Windows: `.venv\Scripts\python.exe`

-   Mac/Linux: `.venv/bin/python`



Solution:

Ensure Jupyter extension is installed
Install ipykernel in your environment:

uv pip install ipykernel

Select the .venv kernel when opening a notebook
Restart VS Code if needed




Solution:

Ensure you‚Äôve selected the correct Python interpreter
Check that python.analysis.extraPaths includes your project root
Reload VS Code window




Solution:

Don‚Äôt use sudo with uv commands
Ensure you have write permissions to the project directory
On Windows, run terminal as regular user (not administrator)




Possible causes:

First run always takes longer
Slow internet connection
Antivirus scanning

Solutions:

Be patient on first run
Disable antivirus temporarily for .venv folder
Use uv sync --offline if you‚Äôve run it before








Keep all work within this project folder
Use relative paths (or pathlib)
Save scripts with descriptive names: verb_noun.py (e.g., analyze_sales.py)




Good:

clean_data.py
2024_01_15_sales_report.csv
figure_01_scatterplot.png

Bad:

script1.py
final FINAL (2) copy.py
sales data.csv (spaces can be problematic)




In Terminal:
# Always use uv run to ensure correct environment
uv run python scripts

title: Python Setup Workshop
section: Why Program? Why Program in a World of AI?
text:
Why Program? Why Program in a World of AI?


understand code to verify AI outputs
debug when AI gives you broken code
need practice with computational thinking to break problems down
control your data and methods (unlike black-box AI tools)
preserve AGENCY over your research workflow

Think of AI as an assistant, but YOU are still the researcher who needs to understand and validate the work

title: Python Setup Workshop
text:
Why Python?: It‚Äôs popular

Most popular language in research 
Massive ecosystem for research: pandas, numpy, scipy, matplotlib, scikit-learn, etc.

title: Python Setup Workshop
text:
Why Python? It‚Äôs beginner-friendly

highly readable language (good for beginners)

title: Python Setup Workshop
text:
Python Example

numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
average = sum(numbers) / len(numbers)
print(f"Average: {average}")

Average: 3.0

title: Python Setup Workshop
text:
R
numbers <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)
average <- mean(numbers)
print(paste("Average:", average))

title: Python Setup Workshop
text:
Why Python? Other Reasons

Strong community support
Free and open source
Cross-platform
Used across disciplines: from digital humanities to computational biology

title: Python Setup Workshop
text:
Typical Python Setup

Install Python
install an IDE (Integrated Development Environment): software that combines tools for writing, editing, compiling, and debugging code.
Install Python packages to ‚Äúglobal‚Äù environment on your computer

title: Python Setup Workshop
text:
Resulting Problems

IDE can‚Äôt find Python (‚ÄòPython is not recognized as a command‚Äô errors?)
Code that worked on one computer but broke on another? (dependency conflicts)
updating one project causes another not to work
installing the wrong package causes your Python installation to break
Multiple Python versions fighting each other?
your project code works differently on different computers (making collaboration difficult)

title: Python Setup Workshop
text:
Common error messages:

'python' is not recognized as an internal or external command
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pandas'
Python version mismatch
Permission denied

title: Python Setup Workshop
text:
Contents

Introductory presentation
Install: Visual Studio Code + uv + Python (notebook 01)
Create Python Project from Scratch within VSC (notebook 02)

set up project folder
write your first markdown document
write your first script
write your first notebook

Download and Import Existing Project (notebook 03)

title: Python Setup Workshop
section: Recommended Python Set Up Approach: UV + VSC
text:
Recommended Python Set Up Approach: UV + VSC

uv: A new, fast tool that manages everything‚ÄîPython versions,virtual environments, and packages‚Äîall in one place.
Visual Studio Code: A modern editor that works seamlessly with uv and Python.
Project best practices: folder/file organization; file-naming; virtual environment for each project; rigorous documentation

We‚Äôre building good habits from day one, not adding them later.

title: Python Setup Workshop
text:
Project Organization
One folder ‚Äì one project

title: Python Setup Workshop
text:
Project Organization
Folder Organization:
my-research-project/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ data/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ raw/              # Original, untouched data
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ processed/        # Cleaned, transformed data
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ code                  # this may include Python scripts (.py) and coding notebooks
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ results/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ figures/          # Plots and visualizations
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ tables/           # Output tables/statistics
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ docs/                 # Documentation, notes
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .gitignore           # Tell git what NOT to track
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md            # Project description and instructions
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ pyproject.toml       # Python dependencies (with uv)

title: Python Setup Workshop
text:
Project Organization
Why this structure?
+ Separation of concerns: Raw data stays pristine, processed data is separate

+ Findability: Six months from now, you'll know where everything is
+ Collaboration: Others can navigate your project easily

+ Scalability: Works for small and large projects
Key principles:
+ Keep raw data in data/raw/ and NEVER modify it directly
+ All data processing should be scripted and reproducible
+ Results should be generated by code, not manually created
+ One project = one self-contained folder"

title: Python Setup Workshop
text:
File Naming Conventions
Some common conventions:

Lowercase with underscores: my-script.py or my_script.py
Be descriptive: Names should tell you what the file contains or does
NO SPACES: For file names, you should replace whitespace with hyphens or underscores instead. Spaces cause issues in terminals. For Python code and folders containing Python code, it is recommended to avoid hyphens too as Python has difficulty importing code from folders or files with hyphens or any special characters besides underscores. Using hyphens for data files is perfectly fine.
Avoid special characters with exception of underscore _ whenever possible.
Use number prefixes for sequences: 01_, 02_, 03_ keeps scripts in order
Include dates if relevant: YYYY_MM_DD or YYYYMMDD to format sorts chronologically (you may also use hyphens, i.e.¬†YYYY-MM-DD for data files and other files or folders that DO NOT contain Python code).
Consistent within a project: Pick a style and stick with it

For general file management naming conventions see Harvard‚Äôs guide to file naming.
For Python specific naming conventions (for files and folders, but also for the names of variables, functions, classes, etc. see The Pep 8 Style Guide.

title: Python Setup Workshop
text:
Documentation
Most important document: README.md file. This is where users go to first to learn more about a project.
What goes in a README:

project title & overview
how to set up / get started
how to use
data description
description of other content
how to cite
license information

title: Python Setup Workshop
text:
Dependency Conflicts
Problem

Project A (from 2022) needs pandas version 1.3
Project B (new project) needs pandas version 2.0

If you just install your Python dependencies to a global environment (meaning they can be accessed anywhere on your personal computer) then your Python setup can only work for one of these packages. For example, if you try to run Project A, but you have pandas 2.0 installed on your computer, then you may receive a dependency conflict error.

title: Python Setup Workshop
text:
Solution: Virtual Environments
A virtual environment is like a separate, isolated workspace for each Python project on your computer.
A virtual environment keeps each project‚Äôs packages separate and organized, preventing conflicts and making your code easy to share
Think of it as:

A project-specific toolbox that contains only the tools (packages) you need for that project
A separate room for each project, so things don‚Äôt get mixed up
A backpack you pack differently for each trip/project

Value of Virtual Environments

avoid conflicts
keep things clean
easy sharing
protect your system

Visual
WITHOUT Virtual Environments:
‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
‚îÇ   YOUR COMPUTER             ‚îÇ
‚îÇ                             ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  All Projects ‚Üí One Big     ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  Messy Pile of Packages üòµ  ‚îÇ
‚îÇ                             ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  (Conflicts! Confusion!)    ‚îÇ
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò


WITH Virtual Environments:
‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
‚îÇ   YOUR COMPUTER             ‚îÇ
‚îÇ                             ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  Project A ‚Üí üì¶ Its packages ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  Project B ‚Üí üì¶ Its packages ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  Project C ‚Üí üì¶ Its packages ‚îÇ
‚îÇ                             ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  (Clean! Organized! üòä)     ‚îÇ
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò

title: Python Setup Workshop
text: Version Control (Git)

title: Python Setup Workshop
text:
IDEs (Integrated Development Environments)
An IDE is your coding workspace. Some examples (Visual Studio Code, Pycharm, Spyder, etc.). Today we are using Visual Studio Code (VSC) because‚Äù:

Free and open source
Excellent Python support
Built-in git integration
Integrated terminal
IntelliSense (code completion)
Debugging tools
Works with both .py scripts and Jupyter notebooks
Huge extension ecosystem
Works on Windows, Mac, and Linux
